nasal obstruction.context: This is a 5-year-old male, who presents for repeat evaluation of a possible nasal obstruction, questionable sleep apnea.

sleep apnea.context: This is a 5-year-old male, who presents for repeat evaluation of a possible nasal obstruction, questionable sleep apnea.

5-year-old.context: The patient is a 5-year-old male, who was last evaluated by Dr. F approximately one year ago for suspected nasal obstruction, possible sleep apnea.

allergic rhinitis.context: He clearly has some symptoms at this point that would suggest possible allergic rhinitis or chronic rhinitis.

symptoms had resolved.context: All of his symptoms had resolved when he had seen Dr. F, so no surgical plan was made and no further followup was needed.

sleep changes.context: However, the patient reports again today with his mother that they are now having continued symptoms of nasal obstruction and questionable sleep changes.

confusing sleep history.context: Again, the mother gives a confusing sleep history but it does not really sound like he is having apneic events.

apneic events.context: Again, the mother gives a confusing sleep history but it does not really sound like he is having apneic events.

snoring loudly.context: It sounds like he is snoring loudly and does have some nasal obstruction at nighttime.

sniffing.context: He also is sniffing a lot through his nose.

nasal steroids.context: He has been tried on some nasal steroids but they only use this on a p.r.n. basis about one or two days every month and we are unsure if that has even helped at all, probably not.

ear infections.context: The child is not having any problems with his ears including ear infections or hearing.

hearing.context: The child is not having any problems with his ears including ear infections or hearing.

strep throat.context: He is also not having any problems with strep throat.

bleeding diathesis.context: No family history of bleeding diathesis or anesthesia difficulties.

anesthesia difficulties.context: No family history of bleeding diathesis or anesthesia difficulties.

Weight 43 pounds.context: VITAL SIGNS: Weight 43 pounds, height 37 inches, temperature 97.4, pulse 65, and blood pressure 104/48.

height 37 inches.context: VITAL SIGNS: Weight 43 pounds, height 37 inches, temperature 97.4, pulse 65, and blood pressure 104/48.

temperature 97.4.context: VITAL SIGNS: Weight 43 pounds, height 37 inches, temperature 97.4, pulse 65, and blood pressure 104/48.

pulse 65.context: VITAL SIGNS: Weight 43 pounds, height 37 inches, temperature 97.4, pulse 65, and blood pressure 104/48.

blood pressure 104/48.context: VITAL SIGNS: Weight 43 pounds, height 37 inches, temperature 97.4, pulse 65, and blood pressure 104/48.

no acute distress.context: GENERAL: The patient is a well-nourished male in no acute distress.

hyponasal voice.context: Listening to his voice today in the clinic, he does not sound to have a hyponasal voice and has a wide range of consonant pronunciation.

wide range of consonant pronunciation.context: Listening to his voice today in the clinic, he does not sound to have a hyponasal voice and has a wide range of consonant pronunciation.

boggy turbinates bilaterally.context: NOSE: Anterior rhinoscopy does demonstrate boggy turbinates bilaterally with minimal amount of watery rhinorrhea.

watery rhinorrhea.context: NOSE: Anterior rhinoscopy does demonstrate boggy turbinates bilaterally with minimal amount of watery rhinorrhea.

tympanic membranes are clear and intact.context: EARS: The patient tympanic membranes are clear and intact bilaterally. There is no middle ear effusion.

middle ear effusion.context: EARS: The patient tympanic membranes are clear and intact bilaterally. There is no middle ear effusion.

2+ tonsils bilaterally.context: ORAL CAVITY: The patient has 2+ tonsils bilaterally. There are clearly nonobstructive. His uvula is midline.

nonobstructive.context: ORAL CAVITY: The patient has 2+ tonsils bilaterally. There are clearly nonobstructive. His uvula is midline.

uvula is midline.context: ORAL CAVITY: The patient has 2+ tonsils bilaterally. There are clearly nonobstructive. His uvula is midline.

gasping events.context: They deny any actual gasping events.

obstructive events.context: It sounds like true obstructive events.

chronic rhinitis.context: He clearly has some symptoms at this point that would suggest possible allergic rhinitis or chronic rhinitis.

Nasacort Aqua.context: I have given them prescription for Nasacort Aqua one spray to each nostril twice a day.

transnasal exam.context: If he continues to have problems, I think at that point we may consider performing a transnasal exam in the office to examine his adenoid bed and that would really be the only surgical option for this child.

allergy evaluation.context: He may also need an allergy evaluation at that point if he continues to have problems.

sleep study.context: Should the mother still have concerns regarding his sleeping at our next visit or should his symptoms worsen (I did instruct her call us if it worsens), we may even need to pursue a sleep study just to settle that issue once and for all.
